<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 868, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 213, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents the sequence of two transformations in the \(x\text{-}y\) plane given by a stretch parallel to the \(x\text{-axis}\), scale factor \(k\) \((k\neq 0)\), followed by a shear, \(x\text{-axis}\) fixed, with (0, 1) mapped to \((k, 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 144, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 109, 339, 139]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} k & k \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 116, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 456, 680, 476]]<|/det|>
The transformation represented by \(\mathbf{M}\) has a line of invariant points.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(k\), the equation of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 747, 89]]<|/det|>
The unit square \(S\) in the \(x\text{-} y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto the parallelogram \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 102, 591, 121]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(k\), a matrix which transforms \(P\) onto \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 320, 144, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 677, 338]]<|/det|>
Given that the area of \(P\) is \(3k^2\) units \(^2\), find the possible values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 320, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 621, 89]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for all positive integers \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 97, 640, 127]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{n}}{\mathrm{dx}^{n}} (\tan^{-1}x) = P_{n}(x) \left(1 + x^{2}\right)^{-n},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 133, 470, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(P_{n}(x)\) is a polynomial of degree \(n - 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 574, 94]]<|/det|>
The quartic equation \(x^{4} + 2x^{3} - 1 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma , \delta .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 895, 126]]<|/det|>
Find a quartic equation whose roots are \(\alpha^{4}, \beta^{4}, \gamma^{4}, \delta^{4}\) and state the value of \(\alpha^{4} + \beta^{4} + \gamma^{4} + \delta^{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 122, 918, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 440, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^5 + \beta^5 + \gamma^5 + \delta^5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 544, 181, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 544, 440, 562]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^8 + \beta^8 + \gamma^8 + \delta^8\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 543, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 84, 97, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 146, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 78, 923, 128]]<|/det|>
Use the method of differences to find \(\sum_{r=1}^{n} \frac{5k}{(5r+k)(5r+5+k)}\) in terms of \(n\) and \(k\), where \(k\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 108, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 71, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 504, 88]]<|/det|>
Show that the curve with Cartesian equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 97, 601, 121]]<|/det|>
\[(x^{2} + y^{2})^{2} = 6xy\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 131, 411, 152]]<|/det|>
has polar equation \(r^2 = 3 \sin 2\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 917, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 348, 601, 371]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r^2 = 3 \sin 2\theta\), for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 144, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 720, 400]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) and state the maximum distance of a point on \(C\) from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 485, 88]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the region enclosed by \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 918, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 186, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 320, 655, 336]]<|/det|>
Find the maximum distance of a point on \(C\) from the initial line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 320, 918, 336]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 462, 107]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{4x^2 + x + 1}{2x^2 - 7x + 3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 144, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 487, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 918, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 330, 185, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 330, 552, 350]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of any stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 331, 918, 350]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 682, 88]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of any intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 71, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 567, 144, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 559, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \left|\frac{4x^2 + x + 1}{2x^2 - 7x + 3}\right|\) and state the set of values of \(k\) for which \(\left|\frac{4x^2 + x + 1}{2x^2 - 7x + 3}\right| = k\) has 4 distinct real solutions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The lines \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\) have equations \(\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j} - 2\mathbf{k} + \lambda (2\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k})\) and \(\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{i} - 2\mathbf{j} + 9\mathbf{k} + \mu (\mathbf{i} - 4\mathbf{j} + 2\mathbf{k})\) respectively. The plane \(\varPi_{1}\) contains \(l_{1}\) and is parallel to \(l_{2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 737, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of \(\varPi_{1}\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 648, 510]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi_{2}\) contains \(l_{2}\) and the point with coordinates \((2, - 1, 7)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 522, 144, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 522, 489, 541]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(\varPi_{1}\) and \(\varPi_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 522, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 828, 92]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) on \(l_{1}\) and the point \(Q\) on \(l_{2}\) are such that \(PQ\) is perpendicular to both \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 398, 122]]<|/det|>
Find a vector equation for \(PQ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]
